 Black Phoenix,
 You understood me correctly. My point in citing John 20  was to affirm that confession to priests was instituted by Jesus and is a worthwhile practice. 
 
 Notice what the verse says, John 20: 21-23  "Jesus said to them again, 'Peace be with you. As the Father has sent me, even so I send you. And when he had said this, he breathed on them, and said to them, 'Receive the Holy Spirit. If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven; if you retain the sins of any, they are retained." The power of forgiving wasn't the only power given the apostles. How were the apostles to retain a sin? They had to know what sin it was in order to know whether to forgive it or retain it. How were they to know without it being confessed to them? 
 
 If Catholic priests are mediating between God and man then they are mediating in the way Jesus intended. Jesus gave them this power as seen in the verse from John. Because of Apostolic Succession all Catholic Bishops and priests can trace their ordination back to the Apostles. So they have been give this power of absolution in persona Christi.
 
 The scripture you are thinking of about Jesus being the only mediator between God and man is not in John but in the very scripture from Timothy that I cited you, 1 Timothy 2:1-5. But we can't just read one verse from scripture and get the whole picture. Paul wrote this verse and if we look at some of his other writings then we will get a clearer picture of what he thought of mediation.
 
 Many say that there is one mediator between God and man and that is Jesus Christ (1 Timothy 2:5). Jesus is the one mediator of salvation between God and Man. No one else could have done what Jesus did. 
 
 But our salvation also depends on a cooperation with the free gift of grace by the free will given to us. 1 Corinthians 3:9, "For we are God's fellow workers; you are God's field, God's building." Does this make us equal with Jesus? No. But we work with God.
 
 Other verses that indicate our cooperation with God:
 
 2 Corinthians 5:20 and 6:1 "we are ambassadors of Christ, God making his appeal through us...Working together with him, then, we entreat you..." 
 
 Romans 8:16-17  "children of God, and if children, then heirs, heirs of God, FELLOW heirs with Christ, provided that we suffer with him in order that we may also be glorified with him." 
 
 If you look at the first line of chapter 2 of 1 Timothy-a few lines above the mediator quote, you read, "First of all, then, I urge that supplications, prayers, intercessions and thanksgivings be made for all men...This is good, and it is acceptable in the sight of God our Saviour..." Why does Paul ask that we pray and make supplication for others if Jesus' mediation disallows our mediation? (by the power of Jesus' saving act on the cross) What good will our prayers do if Jesus' mediation excludes our intercession and action? Jesus is the primary mediator but others can intercede (Colossians 1:24, 1 Corinthians 3:9). This is why Catholics pray to Mary and the saints, as Paul intended--that is to say we ask them for their prayers just as you ask those living on earth to pray for you. Our intercession takes away nothing from the glory of Christ.
 
 You said that you were inspired by Luther going against everything that the Catholic Church said was right. That was the main problem with Luther. He ended up going against everything in the Catholic Church. He didn't simply go against practices that he felt were not in line with (Catholic) Christian teaching. He ended up going against 1500 years of constant teaching on theology, faith, and morals. That is something you should think about. How did the Church get it wrong all those years? And how did the Church founded by Jesus himself get it wrong? How did the Church get it wrong when Jesus told it that the "gates of hell would not prevail against it?" Luther all of a sudden came up with the right theology????????And then, of course, Calvin came up with the right theology, Zwingli did, John Wesley did, Henry V did, etc. 
 
 I can't remember where I read this or I would cite the author--The events of that time are often called the Reformation. But they would be more accurately called a revolution. Re-form implies that one will return to a form already in place--not invent a totally new form. If one is going to return to a form then what form was there originally? And where did it come from?
